SEARCH
Package sh.brane.core.crypto

Class PrivateKey

java.lang.Object
sh.brane.core.crypto.PrivateKey
All Implemented Interfaces:
Destroyable
public final class PrivateKey extends Object implements Destroyable
Ethereum private key with secp256k1 signing capabilities.

This class provides:

  • Private key loading from hex strings
  • Address derivation from public key
  • Deterministic ECDSA signing (RFC 6979)
  • Public key recovery from signatures
  • Low-s normalization for malleability protection

Usage Example


 PrivateKey key = PrivateKey.fromHex("0x1234...");
 Address address = key.toAddress();

 byte[] messageHash = Keccak256.hash(message);
 Signature signature = key.sign(messageHash);

 Address recovered = PrivateKey.recoverAddress(messageHash, signature);
 assert recovered.equals(address);

Security Considerations

This class implements Destroyable to allow clearing sensitive key material from memory when no longer needed. While Java's BigInteger is immutable and cannot be fully zeroed, calling destroy() will:

  • Null out internal references to prevent further use
  • Mark the key as destroyed, causing subsequent operations to fail
  • Help the garbage collector reclaim memory sooner

For maximum security, call destroy() as soon as the key is no longer needed.

Since:
0.2.0

  • Method Details

    • fromHex

      public static PrivateKey fromHex(String hexString)
      Creates a private key from a hex string.
      Parameters:
      hexString - hex-encoded private key (with or without 0x prefix)
      Returns:
      private key instance
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if hex string is invalid or key is out of range

    • fromBytes

      public static PrivateKey fromBytes(byte[] keyBytes)
      Creates a private key from raw bytes.

      Security note: The input byte array will be zeroed after the key is created to minimize exposure of key material in memory. Callers should not rely on the contents of the array after this method returns.

      Parameters:
      keyBytes - 32-byte private key (will be zeroed after use)
      Returns:
      private key instance
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if key bytes are invalid

    • toAddress

      public Address toAddress()
      Derives the Ethereum address from this private key's public key.

      Algorithm:

      1. Compute uncompressed public key (65 bytes: 0x04 || x || y)
      2. Take Keccak256 hash of the last 64 bytes (skip 0x04 prefix)
      3. Take last 20 bytes of the hash
      Returns:
      Ethereum address
      Throws:
      IllegalStateException - if the key has been destroyed

    • sign

      public Signature sign(byte[] messageHash)
      Signs a message hash using deterministic ECDSA (RFC 6979).

      The signature is automatically normalized to low-s to prevent malleability.

      Parameters:
      messageHash - 32-byte Keccak256 hash of the message
      Returns:
      ECDSA signature with v=0 or v=1 (use with EIP-155 encoding for transactions)
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if message hash is not 32 bytes
      IllegalStateException - if the key has been destroyed

    • signFast

      public Signature signFast(byte[] messageHash)
      Optimized signing that avoids public key recovery.
      Parameters:
      messageHash - 32-byte hash
      Returns:
      Signature with v
      Throws:
      IllegalStateException - if the key has been destroyed

    • recoverAddress

      public static Address recoverAddress(byte[] messageHash, Signature signature)
      Recovers the Ethereum address from a signature and message hash.
      Parameters:
      messageHash - 32-byte hash that was signed
      signature - the signature
      Returns:
      recovered Ethereum address
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if recovery fails

    • destroy

      public void destroy()
      Destroys this private key by clearing internal references.

      After calling this method, any attempt to use the key (sign, toAddress, etc.) will throw an IllegalStateException.

      Note: Due to Java's BigInteger being immutable, this cannot guarantee complete removal of key material from memory. However, it nullifies references to help garbage collection and prevents accidental reuse of the key.

      This method is thread-safe. Concurrent calls to destroy and sign/toAddress will either complete the operation or throw IllegalStateException.

      Specified by:
      destroy in interface Destroyable

    • isDestroyed

      public boolean isDestroyed()
      Returns whether this key has been destroyed.
      Specified by:
      isDestroyed in interface Destroyable
      Returns:
      true if destroy() has been called

    • toString

      public String toString()
      Returns a string representation of this private key.

      For security, the actual private key bytes are never included. Instead, the derived address is shown to help identify the key. If the key has been destroyed, returns "PrivateKey[destroyed]".

      This method is thread-safe with respect to concurrent destroy() calls.

      Overrides:
      toString in class Object
      Returns:
      string representation showing address or destroyed status
